misconceptions.inferred_category_name: No clear notional-machine misconception (correct in-place shift model)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that to right-shift an array with wraparound, you must temporarily save the last element, then copy elements from right-to-left so values aren’t overwritten, then put the saved value at index 0.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: There isn’t a gap here: this matches Java’s actual execution model for arrays (arrays are mutable; assignments overwrite; loop order matters to avoid losing values). The student is using a correct mental model of memory locations (indices) and sequencing of statements.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: No error; the code should produce the expected shifted output for N>0, and safely does nothing for N==0.
